comment._content: All flat caps, but for two bowlers.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Foremen?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Belfast News-Letter 8th March 1888: BELFAST HARBOUR STEAM FERRY BOAT THE BELFAST HARBOUR COMMISSIONERS are prepared to receive TENDERS for the supply of a STEAM FERRY BOAT, with Steel Hull and Direct Acting Engines , in accordance with a Drawing and Specifications, which may be seen at the Office of the Harbour Engineer, T. R. Salmond, Esq, from whom any further information may be obtained. Sealed Tenders, addressed to the undersigned, and endorsed "Tender for Ferry Boat" to be sent in on or before MONDAY, the 22nd proximo. The Commissioners do no bind themselves to accept the lowest or any Tender. W.A. Curry, Secretary. Harbour Office, Belfast. 7th March 1888 The same edition also has a notice from the Harbour Commissioners inviting "TENDERS for the supply of CLOTHING required for the Harbour Police &c". No specific mention of hats.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The minutes of the Belfast Harbour Board, as published in the Belfast News-Letter, April 3rd, 1889, state: "... it was decided to issue a cheque in favour of Messrs. Workman, Clarke, & Company for £342 16s in payment for No 2 ferry-boat, built by that firm." www.gracesguide.co.uk/Workman,_Clark_and_Co In 1890 No 3 ferry boat was reported to have been fitted with fire-extinguishing appliances, having been placed on station in March 1889. But I can't find any mention of No 5.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Getting there... Jan 29th, 1891: "The outlines and build of the new boat, No4, denote safety and swiftness"

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] This is excellent, John! You've already blown 1890 as our date out of the water (if you'll pardon the nautical pun)... You can do it - predicting 1892/3.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms]  The foremen wore bowler hats where I was apprentice in the 1950s. We called those hats "Duts".

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Was Duts local slang or just a made up name?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: P.S. Any help with location for this one gratefully accepted!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Dut was local slang for a bowler hat in North East England when I was an apprentice in the 1950s. www.searchdictionaries.com/?q=bowler+hat "A dictionary of North East dialect" near the page bottom. Published by Northumbria University Press 2004. I also remember Galluses or Gallowses for mens braces. See the signal box photo www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/6981593445

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Does anybody know of an online 1890-ish map of Belfast Harbour?  I am very lost and confused with 18+ tabs of NLI search "Robert French Belfast Ship" open!  Fascinating stuff!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I am trying to get this map to work on Linux Mint 11 but the Java Runtime Environment plugin is not working. maps.osni.gov.uk/MapConsoleHistoricalMaps.aspx The NLI historic maps fizzle out (technical jargon) in Belfast Harbour. See if you can do it in Microsoft Windows.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks that works (Windoze, Chrome for me).  It is complicated to work it out - there is almost too much detail.   Brilliant !

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: I got the map console to work and you can clearly see that this is the eastern end of the Queens Quay (more often referred to as "The Coal Quay" where the travelling cranes operated along its length.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Looks like the boat Bogey putted down the river in from "The African Queen" film... It would be about the same vintage as this one too I believe...

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: The coordinates for this location are 54.605268, -5.915958. This is other side of Lagan from the Pilot Office. It was, as billh35 says, at the end of Queen's Quay Road, beside the Coal Depot. It is shown on my 1902 map providing a service between the Claredon Dock and the Abercorn Basin.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I can't find any reference to no 5 ferry boat. In 1898 the Harbour Board decided to buy a new ferry boat. According to the 1899 annual report report this was ordered (a steam boat capable of carrying 150 passengers) but doesn't  mention whether this is No 5 (or  6 , 7 or 8 for that matter).  It might be buried in the columns of the Belfast news-Letter, but there were lengthy meetings every two months, reported in detail, and I could well have missed it.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks about the Duts, and it's really interesting that you say you "also remember Galluses or Gallowses for mens braces" in the North-East of England as swordscookie left a note on this one about "braces or gallasses" as his Western friends would call them. (Think he meant West of Ireland?)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]  "Galluses" - we don't know how many words came over from Ireland in the 1800s. My Dad's ancestors came from Donegal to work in the coal mines of Lancashire and County Durham.
My Mam's granddad came from County Mayo.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] Alan Godfrey has produced some excellent 25inch=1 mile paper maps, only £2.50 each Antrim www.alangodfreymaps.co.uk/antrim.htm County Down www.alangodfreymaps.co.uk/down.htm Usual disclaimer...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Under 'gallows' the OED has: 6. ‘Suspenders’ for trousers; braces. Now dial., Sc. and U.S., in the form gallowses, whence occas. gallows for a single brace. Freq. in the form gallus in the U.S. The first citation is from a 1730 dictionary, so it must have been in common use long before then.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: On the grounds that it must have taken a year or two to order/build a ferry, and taking into account all of [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner]'s research, do we think it'd be safe enough to go for 1893 as a date for this one?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Before you set the date at 1893, I am wondering about those two (sister?) ships being built at Harland & Wolff. Probably not the 'Teutonic' and 'Majestic' (constructed 1887-9, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Teutonic_(1889) ), but maybe another pair of liners which will be recorded somewhere? No idea how to find out ...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I'll hang fire on the dating then, no problem!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Full list of H&W production is here en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harland_and_Wolff#List_of_ships_built Both ships seem to be at same stage of build and would therefore launch fairly close together which makes 1893 seem wrong - I would suggest they are the SS Manitoba and Mohawk both of which launched in 1892 around the same time.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Unfortunately that list is incomplete; eg the 'Teutonic' (see above) is missing. The full H&W records seem to be in the Ulster Folk & Transport Museum ( www.nmni.com/uftm ), but I go round in circles with their website. There are amazing Welch photos (eg HOYFM.HW.H1320 of the 'Oceanic' being built in 1898-9 alongside the 'Afric' and 'Medic' - 3 liners side-by-side. These photos show the use of an inverted "U"-shaped gantry on rails (at the other end of the H&W yard?), rather than the dodgy-looking fixed "T"-shaped gantry in this photo, which looks very unstable. Any H&W history experts out there?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Crikey! H&W were churning out ships at about one a month in c.1892. The Yard Nos. might provide a clue to where they were built in the yard - SS 'Massachusetts' launched December 1891 Yard no.247 - www.atlantictransportline.us/content/20Massachusetts.htm SS 'Manitoba' launched January 1892 Yard no.248 - www.atlantictransportline.us/content/19Manitoba.htm SS 'Mohawk' launched February 1892 Yard no.249 - www.atlantictransportline.us/content/22Mohawk.htm SS 'Mobile' launched November 1892 Yard no.253 - www.atlantictransportline.us/content/21Mobile.htm Also the SS 'Naronic' (White Star Line) launched May 1892 Yard No.251- which has a fascinating story - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Naronic

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: So what were Nos. 250 and 251 which must have been built at the same time?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] 251 - see above.  I have no idea what ships 250, 253, 254 + were, or which was on what slipway.  Sent a message to NMNI.  Watch this space!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is another view of this ferry (or one very similar) from the other side of the Lagan. The two ships seem to be less complete - catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000338185

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: It's the same series without doubt! And probably the same boat as that is the other side of the river at the same point.

comment.author: 47044499@N03
comment._content: I love those tall ships in the background.
